abstract.p: Stewart O'Brien letter responds to July 16 editorial on rats in New York City; recommends garbage disposers to eliminate food wastes that attract rats (M)

block.p: ''Rat Fears'' (editorial, July 16) cites ''every slight change in the way humans handle garbage,'' including expanded street collection and penetrable plastic bags instead of building-based incineration and metal cans, as contributing to New York City's expanding rat problem.

New York residents now have another option, widely practiced across the country: use of food waste disposers that use a building's plumbing system to immediately rid kitchens of food waste. So-called garbage grinders eliminate rotting, odorous food from building basements and from the curb.

''Rat Fears'' (editorial, July 16) cites ''every slight change in the way humans handle garbage,'' including expanded street collection and penetrable plastic bags instead of building-based incineration and metal cans, as contributing to New York City's expanding rat problem.

New York residents now have another option, widely practiced across the country: use of food waste disposers that use a building's plumbing system to immediately rid kitchens of food waste. So-called garbage grinders eliminate rotting, odorous food from building basements and from the curb.
It would be worth comparing New York's rat-to-person ratio with that of cities like Philadelphia, Detroit, Los Angeles and Indianapolis that have required food waste disposers for decades.
STEWART O'BRIEN Executive Director, Plumbing Foundation City of New York New York, July 17, 2000
